abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Northern Irrigation Development Project
            in China. The main objectives of the project were to
            increase the efficiency and profitability of agricultural
            production in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region and to
            alleviate absolute poverty in Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region.
            IDA's performance in project preparation, supervision
            and management was considered adequate and satisfactory. The
            project's overall outcome is Satisfactory with the
            Yinnan Component rated as Highly Satisfactory and Hetao
            Component as Satisfactory due to the latter two-year delay
            in completing the water management monitoring system on the
            Trunk Canal. The key lessons learned include: (a) poverty
            reduction through land settlement is a viable long-term
            intervention when planned and executed systematically; (b)
            successful land settlement requires careful selection of
            settlers based on well-informed process, suitable settlement
            sites, provision of essential basic infrastructure and
            social services, and government preferential policy
            incentives and support in the initial years of settlement;
            (c) appropriate cost recovery policy over a reasonable
            period from settlers will induce a sense of responsibility
            and obligation to succeed in the new environment; (d)
            water-saving technologies should be used in irrigation areas
            supplied with multistage pumping of water at a high cost so
            as to maximize the economic return and use of water; (e)
            consultant services provided jointly by foreign and local
            consultants were economical and efficient, as evident in the
            planning and design of the Hetao Trunk Canal Water
            Management Monitoring System; and (f) foreign exchange
            losses can be minimized by timing procurement of imported
            goods at the time when foreign exchange rates were stable.
